title: Mayan Ruins Explorer: 10 Days
subtitle: Ancient Cities of the Maya World
meta_title: Mayan Ruins Itinerary 10 Days - Chichén Itzá, Palenque, Tulum 2025
meta_description: 10-day Mayan ruins itinerary: Chichén Itzá, Uxmal, Palenque, Calakmul, Tulum, and more. Complete guide to Mexico's ancient Maya archaeological sites.
hero_alt: El Castillo pyramid at Chichén Itzá
introduction: The ancient Maya built one of history's most sophisticated civilizations across the Yucatán Peninsula and beyond. This 10-day itinerary takes you to their greatest cities—from the iconic Chichén Itzá to the jungle-wrapped temples of Palenque to the remote wilderness of Calakmul. You'll gain deep understanding of Maya astronomy, architecture, politics, and daily life.
best_time: November-April (dry season, cooler temperatures for ruin exploration)
highlights: Chichén Itzá - New Wonder of the World
Palenque - Jungle-shrouded royal city with famous tomb
Calakmul - Remote superpower in the biosphere
Tulum - Only major Maya city on the Caribbean coast
Lesser-known gems: Edzná, Kabah, Ek Balam, Cobá

days.title: Arrive Mérida - Gateway to the Maya World
days.description: Begin in the elegant colonial capital of Yucatán state.

activities.title: Arrive Mérida
activities.description: Fly into Mérida International Airport (MID). Transfer to your hotel in the historic centro. Mérida is one of Mexico's safest, most charming cities.
activities.tips: Mérida is a great base for Maya ruins. It's called 'La Ciudad Blanca' for its white limestone buildings. The centro is walkable and beautiful.

activities.title: Walk the Centro Histórico
activities.description: Explore the main plaza, San Ildefonso Cathedral (oldest in the Americas mainland), and Paseo de Montejo boulevard with its French-style mansions.
activities.tips: The cathedral was built using stones from Maya temples. Mérida was built atop the Maya city of T'hó. History is everywhere.

activities.title: Yucatecan Dinner
activities.description: Try regional specialties: cochinita pibil (slow-roasted pork), papadzules (egg enchiladas), or poc chuc (grilled pork).
activities.tips: La Chaya Maya and Apoala serve excellent Yucatecan cuisine. The food here is distinctly different from other Mexican regions.

days.title: Chichén Itzá - Wonder of the World
days.description: Visit the most famous Maya site and New Wonder of the World.

activities.title: Early Departure
activities.description: Leave Mérida early to arrive at Chichén Itzá when it opens (8 AM). Beat the heat and tour bus crowds.
activities.tips: Hire a driver or join a small tour. The site gets extremely crowded and hot by midday. Early is essential.

activities.title: Explore Chichén Itzá
activities.description: See El Castillo pyramid (aligned with equinox), the Great Ball Court (largest in Mesoamerica), Temple of Warriors, and the Sacred Cenote.
activities.tips: Hire a guide at the entrance for context—the astronomy, acoustics, and symbolism are mind-blowing. The clap echo at the pyramid is famous.

activities.title: Cenote Ik Kil
activities.description: Cool off at this stunning cenote near Chichén Itzá. Vines hang to the water, sunlight streams through—magical swimming experience.
activities.tips: Touristy but worth it. Entry ~$150 MXN. The jump from the platform is exhilarating. Showers and lockers available.

activities.title: Lunch & Valladolid
activities.description: Stop in the colonial town of Valladolid for late lunch. Walk the pretty zócalo and visit Cenote Zací in town.
activities.tips: Valladolid is charming and much less touristy than it should be. Good option for overnight if you want to stay near ruins.

activities.title: Return to Mérida
activities.description: Drive back to Mérida. Evening at leisure to rest and explore.
activities.tips: Or stay in Valladolid to be closer to tomorrow's Ek Balam visit.

days.title: Ek Balam & Uxmal
days.description: Two contrasting sites: intimate jungle ruins and Puuc architectural perfection.

activities.title: Ek Balam
activities.description: Drive to this lesser-known site with remarkably preserved stucco sculptures. The main pyramid (Acropolis) has a stunning carved monster mouth entrance and is climbable.
activities.tips: From Valladolid: 30 min. From Mérida: 2 hours. Much less crowded than Chichén. You can still climb this pyramid—the view is incredible.

activities.title: Drive to Uxmal
activities.description: Cross the Yucatán to the Puuc region. The Puuc hills have their own Maya architectural style—considered the most refined.
activities.tips: Long drive but worth it. Consider stopping in Mérida briefly or driving direct. Uxmal is south of Mérida.

activities.title: Uxmal
activities.description: Explore this UNESCO site, considered the finest example of Puuc architecture. The Pyramid of the Magician's unique oval shape, the Nunnery Quadrangle's intricate facades, and the Governor's Palace are highlights.
activities.tips: Entry $494 MXN (higher than others, worth it). Bring water—no shade. The stonework details here surpass even Chichén. Truly breathtaking craftsmanship.

activities.title: Uxmal Light & Sound Show (Optional)
activities.description: Evening sound and light show illuminates the ruins with Maya myths narrated.
activities.tips: Check schedule—not every night. Atmospheric but cheesy narration. The illuminated ruins are beautiful regardless.

days.accommodation: Hotel near Uxmal or return to Mérida

days.title: Puuc Route - Kabah & Beyond
days.description: Explore the Puuc Route's smaller but equally impressive sites.

activities.title: Kabah
activities.description: Just 20 minutes from Uxmal, Kabah features the incredible Palace of Masks—a facade covered with hundreds of Chaac (rain god) masks.
activities.tips: Entry ~$55 MXN. Less visited than Uxmal. The mask facade is one of Maya architecture's most intense expressions. Don't miss the arch.

activities.title: Sayil & Labná
activities.description: Continue on the Puuc Route to these smaller sites. Sayil has a massive palace, Labná has a famous ceremonial arch.
activities.tips: These sites are nearly empty. Explore at your pace. The Puuc Route gives sense of the region's ancient prosperity.

activities.title: Drive to Campeche
activities.description: Head to the walled colonial city of Campeche, a UNESCO World Heritage site and gateway to Calakmul.
activities.tips: Campeche is underrated—beautiful colored buildings, city walls, excellent seafood. Good base for Calakmul.

activities.title: Explore Campeche
activities.description: Walk the walled city centro, see the bastions and gates, enjoy the malecón (waterfront) at sunset.
activities.tips: The colored buildings in the centro are photogenic. Much quieter than Mérida. Campeche has excellent, affordable seafood.

activities.title: Seafood Dinner
activities.description: Campeche is famous for seafood. Try pan de cazón (dogfish layered with tortillas), shrimp cocktails, or fresh fish.
activities.tips: La Pigua is famous but touristy. Marganzo has great seafood at better prices. Eat by the water.

days.title: Edzná & Travel to Calakmul
days.description: Visit an underrated site, then head deep into the biosphere.

activities.title: Edzná
activities.description: 45 minutes from Campeche, this site combines multiple Maya styles. The Five-Story Building is unique—combining a palace base with a temple pyramid top.
activities.tips: Entry ~$75 MXN. Often empty. Excellent for photos and contemplation. The main plaza's acoustics are impressive.

activities.title: Drive to Calakmul Biosphere
activities.description: Long drive (4+ hours) into the massive jungle biosphere reserve. The road passes through pristine forest—watch for wildlife.
activities.tips: Fill up on gas before entering the reserve. The access road (60km) is slow but scenic. You'll see toucans, monkeys, possibly jaguar tracks.

activities.title: Arrive & Settle
activities.description: Check into eco-lodge near the ruins. Options are basic but atmospheric—you're in the middle of the jungle.
activities.tips: Book ahead—limited accommodations. Puerta Calakmul and Chicanna Ecovillage are options. Bring bug spray, flashlight.

activities.title: Jungle Evening
activities.description: Listen to howler monkeys, bird calls, and jungle sounds. Early night for tomorrow's dawn exploration.
activities.tips: The jungle at night is LOUD. Embrace it. You're in one of the most biodiverse places in Mexico.

days.title: Calakmul - The Lost Superpower
days.description: Explore one of the Maya world's most powerful cities, hidden in jungle.

activities.title: Dawn Entry to Calakmul
activities.description: Enter the reserve at first light. The 60km access road takes an hour. Arrive at the ruins as they open. Morning mist, wildlife active, no crowds.
activities.tips: Calakmul opens at 8 AM but the drive takes time. You might be the only visitors. Bring water, food—no services inside.

activities.title: Explore Calakmul
activities.description: This was Tikal's great rival, capital of the 'Snake Kingdom.' Climb Structure I and II—among the tallest Maya pyramids. At the top, you see only jungle to the horizon.
activities.tips: Bring sturdy shoes, lots of water, snacks. The site is HUGE and mostly unexcavated—mounds everywhere are buried temples. The view from Structure II is life-changing.

activities.title: Wildlife Watching
activities.description: Drive slowly out of the reserve watching for wildlife. Spider and howler monkeys, toucans, ocellated turkeys, and occasionally jaguar or puma sightings.
activities.tips: Early morning and late afternoon are best for animals. Stop at pullouts and listen. The forest is teeming with life.

activities.title: Chicanna or Becán (Optional)
activities.description: Small sites near Calakmul with Rio Bec style architecture—monster mouth doorways and false pyramid temples.
activities.tips: Chicanna has amazing monster mouth doorways. Becán is a fortified city with moat. Both are nearly empty and atmospheric.

activities.title: Rest at Lodge
activities.description: Another night in the jungle. Process the incredible day.
activities.tips: Tomorrow is another long drive to Palenque. Rest well.

days.title: Calakmul to Palenque
days.description: Cross Chiapas to another of the Maya world's greatest cities.

activities.title: Drive to Palenque
activities.description: 4-5 hour drive west through jungle and farmland into Chiapas state. The landscape gradually changes.
activities.tips: Fill gas before leaving. The road is good but long. Consider audiobook or podcast about Maya history to enrich tomorrow's visit.

activities.title: Arrive Palenque Area
activities.description: Head to El Panchan or hotels near the ruins rather than Palenque town. Jungle setting, backpacker vibes, restaurants, close to ruins.
activities.tips: El Panchan is a jungle settlement with cheap cabañas and good restaurants. More atmospheric than town hotels.

activities.title: Rest & Acclimatize
activities.description: Palenque is hot and humid. Rest during peak heat. Prepare for early morning ruins visit.
activities.tips: Hydrate constantly. The humidity is intense here. Hammock time is appropriate.

activities.title: Dinner at El Panchan
activities.description: Several jungle restaurants with good food, live music some nights, bonfire vibes.
activities.tips: Don Mucho's is popular. Listen for howler monkeys at dusk—they're incredibly loud. The jungle evening atmosphere is special.

days.accommodation: El Panchan or hotel near Palenque ruins

days.title: Palenque - Jungle City of Kings
days.description: Explore one of the Maya world's most artistic and atmospheric sites.

activities.title: Early Entry to Palenque
activities.description: Walk from El Panchan (20 min) or take colectivo. Arrive at opening (8 AM) for cooler temperatures, morning mist, and howler monkey chorus.
activities.tips: Entry ~$85 MXN. The early morning atmosphere—mist, jungle sounds, few people—is magical. This is why you came early.

activities.title: Temple of Inscriptions & Palace
activities.description: See King Pakal's famous tomb location (the jade mask is in Mexico City's anthropology museum). Climb the Palace tower for views over the jungle canopy.
activities.tips: You can't enter the tomb anymore but can see into it. The carved panels and stucco work are Maya art at its finest. The palace complex is intricate.

activities.title: Cross of Group & Jungle Trails
activities.description: Hike to the Temple of the Cross group—three temples on a hillside with incredible roof combs and carvings. Continue on jungle trails to smaller temples.
activities.tips: The Cross group is steep but rewarding. Only 5% of Palenque is excavated—mounds in the jungle are unexcavated temples. Mind-bending scale.

activities.title: Exit via Waterfalls
activities.description: Take the selva (jungle) exit path passing waterfalls and swimming holes. Refreshing way to end the hot ruins visit.
activities.tips: Bring swimsuit! The falls are beautiful and you'll be sweaty. Colectivos wait at the lower entrance to return you to town/El Panchan.

activities.title: Lunch & Rest
activities.description: Return to base, lunch, hammock time during peak heat.
activities.tips: This is appropriate Palenque behavior. The heat is serious. Rest and hydrate.

activities.title: Evening
activities.description: Dinner and perhaps live music at El Panchan.
activities.tips: Some nights have fire performances, drum circles. The jungle backpacker community is social and international.

days.title: Palenque to Tulum
days.description: Long travel day to the Caribbean coast for final ruins.

activities.title: Fly or Bus to Cancún/Tulum
activities.description: Option A: Small plane from Palenque to Cancún (seasonal). Option B: Long bus (12+ hours) to Tulum/Playa. Option C: Fly via Mexico City (longer but comfortable).
activities.tips: Flying saves massive time if available. Otherwise, ADO first-class bus is comfortable but long. Book ahead.

activities.title: Arrive Tulum Area
activities.description: Check into hotel in Tulum. The Caribbean awaits.
activities.tips: Tulum Pueblo is cheaper and more authentic than beach zone. Beach is 5-10 min by bike.

activities.title: Beach Dinner
activities.description: First sight of Caribbean turquoise. Dinner with ocean views.
activities.tips: You've earned beach relaxation. The contrast from jungle to Caribbean is dramatic.

days.title: Tulum & Cobá - Coastal & Jungle Ruins
days.description: Finish with clifftop Caribbean ruins and the tallest climbable pyramid.

activities.title: Tulum Ruins
activities.description: Arrive when the clifftop ruins open. The only major Maya coastal city. Incredible views over Caribbean turquoise.
activities.tips: Entry ~$85 MXN. The ruins are small but the setting is unmatched. Beach below is swimmable. Come early before cruise ship crowds.

activities.title: Drive to Cobá
activities.description: 45 minutes inland to Cobá, a massive site in the jungle. Still possible to climb the main pyramid—the tallest you can ascend in Yucatán.
activities.tips: Entry ~$85 MXN. Rent a bike or hire a bike taxi to cover the spread-out site. The climb up Nohoch Mul pyramid (120 steps, 42m high) is thrilling—and the jungle view from top is spectacular.

activities.title: Cenote Swim
activities.description: Several cenotes near Cobá. Cool off after climbing pyramids in the heat.
activities.tips: Cenote Choo-Ha, Tamcach-Ha, and Multum-Ha are nearby. Refreshing end to 10 days of ruins.

activities.title: Final Evening
activities.description: Return to Tulum for Caribbean sunset. Reflect on 10 days exploring one of humanity's great civilizations.
activities.tips: You've seen Maya cities spanning a thousand years—from superpowers like Calakmul to coastal outposts like Tulum. Toast to the ancient Maya.

practical_info.getting_there: Fly into Mérida (MID) or Cancún (CUN). This itinerary starts Mérida, ends Tulum/Cancún. Rent a car or use combination of tours, buses, and drivers.
practical_info.getting_around: Rental car gives most flexibility for this itinerary, especially for Puuc Route and Calakmul. Some sites accessible by bus/colectivo.
practical_info.where_to_stay: Mérida centro, Campeche centro, eco-lodges near Calakmul, El Panchan (Palenque), Tulum.
practical_info.money: Budget $150-250/day including car rental, entry fees, accommodations, and meals. Entry fees add up—budget $30-50 total for sites.
practical_info.best_guides: Hire local guides at major sites (Chichén, Uxmal, Palenque). They provide context that transforms the experience. $40-60 for 2-hour tour.
